articles.title: The Life and Legacy of Fashion Designer Paul Costelloe
articles.summary: Paul Costelloe, a prominent Irish fashion designer, passed away at the age of 80 in London after a short illness, as announced by his family. He was a key figure in British and Irish fashion, renowned for being the personal designer to Diana, Princess of Wales, from 1983 until her death in 1997. Born in Dublin, Costelloe was influenced by his father's raincoat manufacturing business and pursued fashion education at the Grafton Academy in Dublin and the Chambre Syndicale de la Haute Couture in Paris. In 1979, he established Paul Costelloe Collections, presenting his work at major fashion weeks in London, Paris, Milan, and New York. His designs often featured traditional Irish fabrics such as linen and tweed, highlighting his cultural heritage. Costelloe collaborated with retailers like Dunnes Stores and participated in events like Ireland Fashion Week. However, he faced criticism in 1998 for comments about Irish women's style, though he later noted Ireland's evolving European identity in a recent interview. His career demonstrates innovation in fashion while maintaining Irish roots, and his passing marks the end of an era in the fashion world.

articles.title: Radiohead deliver a spell-binding, hit-packed set in London
articles.summary:
"Whenever you're ready," says Thom Yorke, adopting the tone of a schoolteacher waiting for an unruly class to settle down, as Radiohead get ready to play their encore at London's O2 Arena.

It's a rare flash of humour from the frontman, whose onstage utterings are mostly limited to mumbled "thank yous". But it's also an acknowledgment of how long fans have been waiting for this show.

It is now 10 years since Radiohead last released new material, and 99 months since their last UK gig.

Anticipation for their return has been building ever since they announced a limited run of concerts in September. Setlists from early shows in Spain and Italy have generated news stories ("Radiohead play Nice Dream for the first time since 2009"), as fans pore over the song choices.

According to one source, they've rehearsed 65 different numbers.

At the O2, the band sift through their entire discography - from the arena rock anthems of 1994's The Bends to the celestial ballads of A Moon Shaped Pool, via the layered electronics of Kid A, currently celebrating its 25th anniversary.

There are some signs that Radiohead are a bit rusty. A few timing and tuning issues crop up, which could easily be the result of a first night in a new venue, but which feel odd for a band of such technical proficiency.

But when it comes together, it's a rapturous, spell-binding sight.

They begin with the spacey, hypnotic Planet Telex, and follow it up with a crunchy version of 2+2=5, written in 2003 as a reaction to George W Bush's "War on Terror", and taking on new urgency in a world where political norms have seemingly been turned upside down.

By the third song, Sit Down, Stand Up, they're flexing their musical muscles, with an extended outro of percussive lunacy, aided by US session musician Chris Vatalaro.

His addition to the line-up is a giveaway. Radiohead's secret sauce has always been their rhythm section - who manage to locate sinewy, danceable grooves even when presented with their bandmate's most challenging material.

The prowling bassline of National Anthem and the slamming drum loops of Idioteque, in particular, give the audience ample opportunity to jump up and down.

That said, it's amusing to watch bassist Colin Greenwood try (and fail) to get the crowd clapping in time to the glitchy and unconventional rhythms of 15 Step.

Instead, most of them simply bob their heads up and down in unified appreciation of the music. At times, it looks like a convention of nodding dogs.

Cushioned between the more experimental songs, however, were the real crowd-pleasers: An elegiac version of Lucky, a beautifully twisted No Surprises and a genuinely sublime version of Weird Fishes/Arpeggi.

articles.title: Cobolli's Epic Tie-Break Victory Propels Italy to Davis Cup Final
articles.summary: In a thrilling Davis Cup semifinal match, Italian tennis player Flavio Cobolli secured a dramatic victory over Belgium's Zizou Bergs after a grueling 32-point tie-break. The match, which lasted over three hours, saw Cobolli save seven match points before clinching the win with a score of 6-3, 6-7 (5-7), 7-6 (17-15). His emotional celebration, including tearing off his shirt, highlighted the intense pressure and joy of the moment. This win sends Italy, the two-time defending champions, into the final against either Spain or Germany. Cobolli expressed that achieving this dream was one of the best days of his life, emphasizing the fight for his country, team, and family. Italy's captain, Filippo Volandri, praised Cobolli's heart and determination, noting the team's strong bench support. Despite missing top players like Jannik Sinner and Lorenzo Musetti, Italy aims to become the first nation in 53 years to win three consecutive Davis Cup titles, marking a historic opportunity in the tournament's 125-year history.

articles.title: Rare Superman Comic Discovery Sets Auction Record
articles.summary: In 2024, three brothers discovered a pristine copy of Superman #1 from 1939 while cleaning their late mother's loft in California. The comic, found in a cardboard box under newspapers, was sold for $9.12 million at Heritage Auctions, making it the most expensive comic ever sold. Their mother had kept it since the Great Depression era, and the cool climate helped preserve its condition, earning it a high grade of 9.0 from CGC. This sale broke the previous record held by Action Comics No. 1, which sold for $6 million. The brothers, who remain anonymous, were surprised by the find, as their mom had mentioned an expensive collection but never showed it. This event highlights the growing value of vintage comics in collectibles markets.

articles.title: BBC's Struggle for Relevance Amid Financial Pressures
articles.summary: A report from the House of Commons public accounts committee, composed of MPs, has highlighted that the BBC is under severe pressure to maintain its relevance across all audience groups in the UK. The committee warns that the broadcaster's failure to engage younger audiences and address rising licence fee evasion is jeopardizing its long-term sustainability. Specifically, young people are using the BBC significantly less than older demographics, perceiving it as less aligned with their interests, which threatens the BBC's core mission of universal service. Financially, the BBC is facing substantial losses, with licence fee evasion rising to 12.5%, contributing to over £1.1 billion in potential lost income for 2024/25. This includes £550m from evasion and £617m from people who claim they do not need a licence, such as those not watching live TV. The MPs also criticize local decisions, like moving operations to cities such as Manchester or Birmingham, for potentially neglecting smaller communities. In response, the BBC acknowledges the need for licence fee reform but emphasizes the importance of preserving its role as a public broadcaster. The situation underscores broader challenges in adapting to changing media consumption habits and ensuring fairness to licence fee payers.

articles.title: Germany's Dramatic Davis Cup Victory
articles.summary: In a highly competitive Davis Cup quarter-final, Germany staged an impressive comeback to defeat Argentina 2-1, securing a spot in the semi-finals against Spain. The match hinged on the doubles rubber, where German pair Kevin Krawietz and Tim Puetz faced immense pressure, saving three match points in a tense final-set tie-break to win 4-6, 6-4, 7-6 (12-10). Earlier, Argentina had taken the lead with Tomas Etcheverry's strong performance in singles, but Alexander Zverev leveled the tie by defeating Francisco Cerundolo. Zverev, though not at his peak, delivered crucial points in tie-breaks. The doubles match was a rollercoaster, with Germany missing four match points before clinching victory. This win is significant as Germany aims for their first final since 1993, highlighting the team's resilience. Meanwhile, Spain advanced by beating the Czech Republic, setting up an exciting semi-final in Bologna. The Davis Cup emphasizes national pride and team dynamics in tennis.
